A fun puzzle-like game with a fairly original first person twist. Quite unique in the way that roughly 90% of the game works as a tutorial, but it does not ever bother you. It just works great. Requires mostly planning, but there are some pieces wanting reacton and quick thinking as well. Fun game that does not take too long to play though.

This is a fantastic first person shooting puzzle game based around boxes, switches and of course the portal. Shoot a blue portal and exit a red portal. Simple stuff like that. There is no fat in this game and seasoned players can probably beat it in an hour, but that is good. The game is kept short and sweet all while being pushed forward by a narrator / villain GLaDOS or however it is spelled. The passive aggressive villain. Anyway, this game is a joy and only a matter of time before it is free. It uses Valve's source engine.

YOUR BUSINESS IS APPRECIATED.

What can I say about this game that hasn't already been said? If you haven't had a chance to play this title, you're really missing out.

A creative first person puzzler like no other. Use the portal gun to generate portable wormholes to navigate your way through various floors of a testing facility, all the while being given pointers and guided by a mysterious electronic voice.

It's difficult to go into details without spoiling the parts of the game that are so phenomenal, so just do yourself a favor.

If you've never played Portal, stop reading this and go buy it now and give it a shot, even if it doesn't look like the game for you. You'll thank yourself later.

Updated Review: 12/16/13

This was a triumph.  I'm making a note here, huge success.  This is the game that became a phenomenon and portaled its way into popular culture.  

The reason for Portal's fame and success is probably that it was so original.  Non-violent, absurdly funny, moderately disturbing, and a catchy theme song at the end, it was different from most games of the time.  

The plot involved a woman waking up in a strange laboratory with a robotic voice talking her through  series of tests involving portals and physics.  At first the voice seems eager to help, but it becomes more clear with each level that something is not right at Aperture Science, and it isn't just the question of cake.  The story is not told through dialog or cutscenes, instead it unfolds by progressing through stages and what you see and hear during the game.  There is no narration, only the voice of GLaDOS as she tells you how to perform the tests.  Yet the story it tells is a fascinating and rich one.

While the game is based on Half-Life 2's source engine, and functions like a first-person shooter, it is not a shooting game.  The point of the game is to place portals in different areas to move across rooms or gain momentum, and moving objects around to activate switches.  It is effectively a puzzle game, but plays like a modern FPS.  

The only thing wrong with this game is that it is short.  Fortunately, they made a second one to make up for it.

But look at me still talking, when there's science to do...

----------

Original Review: July 30, 2012

Amazing.  This is one of the most original and intriguing games I've ever played.  If you are losing faith in the idea of modern gaming having any kind of innovation, you need to play this.  It's a short game.  It's not a partcularly hard game.  It's not a very violent shoot-em-up game...you don't even use weapons.  What you have is a puzzle game in first person, with an amazing background plot.  This game has a lot of suspense, and there reaches a point where you realize there's a lot more going on than just a few mental exercises.  It goes from pleasantly brainy to outright horrific, until the whole concept of the game unravels into a paranoid journey into Aperture Science.  One of the most involving and entertaining games of all time.  And then, after the cake, there is a sequel...
Although short, one of the most intriguing, exciting, and mind-boggling games ever.
Masterpiece

There's nothing about this game that hasn't already been said.

A 1st person, spacial, puzzle game where you bypass obstacles (in numerous obstacle test chambers) using a portal gun to place 2 interconnected wormhole ends.  Lab rats never had it so good!  Several of the test chambers have multiple solutions and the overall story is spoon-fed to you...until it all starts to become clear!

Великолепная игра! 10/10! Не люблю логические головоломки, но тут не устоял. Время не властно над Portal'ом. Интригующий сюжет, ненавязчивое, всегда в тему музыкальное сопровождение, удобный геймплей, забавный "железный юмор" от роботов, постепенное возрастание сложности, позволяющее плавно влиться в игру. Что может быть лучше?
И да, учитесь мыслить портально!..)

Portal es un FPS con toques de puzzle en el que cambiaremos las balas, por portales.

En él, somos Chell, una "rata de laboratorio" sometida a cámaras de prueba (las cuales algunas incluyen elementos que pueden matarnos) que gracias a nuestra pistola de portales, podremos hacer frente.

Todo y ser un juego corto de narices (yo me lo pasé como en 5 horas, pero se puede pasar en mucho menos), deja muy buen sabor de boca.
 
Y aunque sea corto, no vamos a negar que es de los FPS más originales que puedes echarte en cara.

El final es de los mejores que he visto jamás en un videojuego.

100% recomendado.
Excelente jogo, vale apena jogar

Das erste Portal war super und ein echter Überraschungshit, den niemand vor der Veröffentlichung so richtig auf dem Schirm hatte. Das Tolle: Als Bestandteil der Orange Box war Portal extrem günstig zu haben. Bei Teil zwei sah das schon anders aus. Der Hype vor dem Release war riesig, der Preis auch: Aufgrund des großen Erfolgs des ersten Teils dachte man sich bei Valve wohl, für den zweiten Teil durchaus den Vollpreis verlangen zu können.

My only qualm with this game is that it's short, but it's by far one of the best short gaming experiences I've ever had.  Witty and clever...everyone with even an ounce of puzzle or FPS interest should play this game through at least once.

You know how people will review or advertise a game's replayability, touting all the changes, alternate endings, or new characters to unlock?  This game is so good it had me playing it all the way through from start to finish many times over just for the sake of it with really nothing new to gain.  One of the best games I've ever played, hands down.

Puzzle puzzle puzzle

Portal is truly an original concept with its dimensional puzzle-based gameplay as well as a masteful construction in terms of gameplay, level design, and sparse storytelling.  It has distinctive visuals, great character(s), and some of the best subtle, dark humor I have ever seen.  The length is short, but the game certainly does not outstay its welcome.

Everyone and their grandma should play this game.

"All the unanimous praise can't be that wrong," I thought when I bought this game despite disliking FPSes. Well, Portal certainly changed that, so I'll just go ahead and say that all the unanimous praise really isn't wrong. It's fun, it's challenging and it has one of the - in my humble opinion at least - greatest stories in gaming. A must-play if you want to look your fellow gamers in the eye.
Genialt spil med en fantastisk "historie". Er meget glad for at jeg gik tilbage og spillede Portal 1 før jeg gik igang med Portal 2.

Insightful to the human mind to bear more fruit than the fruit of the action itself,

To think before acting is widely encouraged,

Calculating as it may, one needs a tedious will to overcome a sense of frustration when faced with a tool of limitless capabilities.

Try and fare teh course with an open mind of possibilities and impossibilities, to bear the sweetest fruit of the core.

For without heeding such warnings, will you fall, before it is too late.

So I give unto you my advice, follow your're heart as an individual, try and stay true to yourself and not follow orders from others that seem weird....

One's journey is not how far or short the journey itself ends. But rather the knowledge  that is gained right after the journey that bears the whole existence of learning it. 

Utilizing *Portals* is only one way to open the boundaries of more Portals

Will you take that initiative?
